intro: Potamogeton longiligulatus, commonly known as the long-ligule pondweed, is a submerged aquatic plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It is characterized by its slender, ribbon-like leaves that are typically 10–30 cm in length and have a distinct ligule, a small, membranous structure at the base. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers that are usually clustered in spikes, and it reproduces both sexually and asexually through rhizomes. It thrives in shallow, freshwater environments such as lakes, ponds, and slow-moving streams. Due to its dense growth, it plays an important role in stabilizing sediments and providing habitat for aquatic invertebrates and fish.
